newsitem.title: USA: ADR REPORT - Oils strengthen in quiet trade.
newsitem.headline: ADR REPORT - Oils strengthen in quiet trade.

text.p: Foreign oil companies strengthened Tuesday to highlight quiet trade in American Depositary Receipts (ADRs).

Traders said activity was subdued as the central bank's Federal Open Market Committee met to map interest rate strategy. The policy-setting panel is expected to announce results of the meeting at 1415 EDT/1815 GMT, but analysts have said they expect no change in short-term rates.
British Petroleum Co Plc rose 1-11/16 to 82-13/16 after NatWest analyst Fergus MacLeod raised his earnings forecast for the company.

MacLeod also reiterated his add recommendations for Royal Dutch Petroleum Co and Shell Transport and Trading Co Plc. Shell rose one to 41-1/2 and Royal Dutch, among the most-active ADRs in New York, was up 1-1/8 to 53-1/4.
French oil major Elf Aquitaine rose 2-13/16 to 55-9/16 after it reported an oil discovery off Angola. The company called the find one of the biggest in Africa.

Israel's Check Point Software Technologies Ltd rose 15/16 to 23-15/16 after Morgan Stanley said it had started coverage of the ADRs with a rating of outperform. Check Point, which makes network security software, was the most-active ADR, with 1.1 million ADRs traded by mid-morning.
Among other technology stocks, Franco-Italian semiconductor maker SGS-Thomson Microelectronics NV rose 3-3/16 to 95-3/16, a 12-month high.
Traders said the boost could have come because computer technology firm Bay Networks Inc said it expected first-quarter revenues to exceed analysts' expectations.

Leading Chinese ADRs sagged amid concerns about a speculative attack on the Hong Kong dollar. Beijing Yanhua Petrochemical Co Ltd fell 1-3/16 to 16-1/2 and Brilliance China Automotive Holdings Ltd was off 1/2 to 8-1/2.
Both ADRs were among percentage-loss leaders on the New York Stock Exchange. Joining them were Japan's Sony Corp, which fell 3-1/16 to 94-11/16, and Kyocera Corp, which dropped 5-1/4 to 150.
Latin American ADRs were quiet. Brazil's Telebras SA rose 3/16 to 126-15/16 and was among the most-active issues on the New York Stock Exchange.
"Volumes have been down and clients are not doing anything at all," a Latin American trader said. "Most of these markets are being driven by traders -- those that are in the office."
Advancers led decliners 257 to 173 among 814 ADRs. The ADR group was up 0.36 percent and volume was 24 million ADRs.
ADRs allow U.S. trade of foreign shares.
